awd_titl_txt: Convexity, Topology, Combinatorics and beyond: An international conference
awd_abstract_narration:
The award will support an international workshop on the mathematics at the
intersection of convex geometry, topology, and combinatorics, or convex
topological combinatorics, for short. This is an important topic because
convex geometric and topological techniques have become a main tool in
discrete mathematics and theoretical computer science. In fact, convex
topological combinatorics has had a impact in application areas such as
algorithm design, computer graphics, mathematical programming, solid
modeling, and computational biology. At the same time, topology and
geometry have benefited from the study of combinatorial structures such as
convex bodies, polyhedra, simplicial complexes, geometric graphs, etc.,
because they appear naturally in relation to important algebraic and
topological spaces such as Grassmanians, toric varieties, configuration
spaces, and others.

This workshop will be the first large international conference in
North-America on the topic of convex topological combinatorics. The event
intends to bring together top international researchers to discuss
developments in these intersecting fields. Besides specific mathematical
research, the meeting will increase the cooperation between mathematical
schools in the USA and Mexico, both of which have many strong researchers
in convex topological combinatorics and a good number of Ph.D students
doing research in these topics. Both groups will benefit from the
interaction that the conference will bring.

por.por_cntn:
This was an international scientific meeting in the intersection of Convexity,
Combinatorics, and Topology. These three mathematical areas, which
can be roughly described as the study of geometric structures with
finitely many buidling blocks, have many  applications, for example one 
speaker described how to design flexible robot arms and how to calculate 
the maximum possible reach of it. Another speaker
discussed the use of these tools to understand DNA. Multiple cellular 
processes such as replication recombination and packing change the topology 
of DNA. Controlling these changes is a key to  ensuring stability inside the cell
(e.g., healthy cell division). The cell uses enzymes to simplify DNA topology. 

This scientific event received partial support from NSF, but was mostly funded by  


CONACYT, the Mexican Mathematical Society and the National University of 
Mexico (UNAM).  One of the key results of the meeting was to strengthen the 
relations between the communities of mathematicians working in these topics 
in the USA and Mexico. For some years now, american and  mexican 
mathematicians have been working on closely related projects, but have 
not been united in one coherent group ready for collaboration. The  meeting 


had a very powerful positive impact on the development of  these


investigations and human resources training for the two communities involved.  


The relationship of the USA to Mexico is important at all levels (as neighboring 


countries), but the scientific and educational connections can help in several


ways. Already young USA Ph.Ds are finding jobs in mexican Universities and


several mexican students have gone to study in the USA. We hope a more


solid relation with Mexico will also help with recruitment of more latino USA 


minorities in the mathematical sciences when students here see there also 


large numbers of latinos involved in science elsewhere. 




We had a total of 33 presentations, a poster session. Speakers came not
only from the USA and Mexico, but also Canada, Russia, France, Germany,
Hungary, and Spain. A good example of international cooperation.
